channel.title: Retro lookin synth (work in progress)
channel.description: Here's where I'm at so far. I started this project last year and have learned so many things along the way I have genuinely no idea where to start lol You might think the inside of this is a huge mess and the connections to that many potentiometers ended up being noise as a result of - it was! - but I came up with a simple solution to fix all this that was actually super inexpensive. I designed a few little breakout boards in Eagle that hold the potentiometers in place (and this keeps them nicely spaced too) I use ribbon cable to connect these tiny little boards To a motherboard! This mother board was the first one one I came up with and I totally messed it up (it was one of the very first things I ever made in Eagle so meh) it had connections for the axoloti to connect to 16 pots directly, then the rest connected to a teensy....I really fucked up the design of it and it was a total loss - but i learned a lot during the process. Heres what the interiors looks like right now. Its pretty tidy and has a lot of space for at least one Axoloti and a couple other boards to rest comfortably Now of course this wouldnt be a very interesting synth if it was nothing but potentiometers so I made a few different flavours of the small breakout boards that can be used for a number of different things (switches, leds, you name it!) You'll notice that currently my synth is missing switches entirely - this is because I found some really nice looking switches that I like a lot more than the ones I designed these boards for so I'm waiting for my new boards for those switches to arrive. Also, making square holes in sheet metal is a huge pain in the ass so I've designed some little enclosure type things to hold my new square switches in circular holes.....also waiting for a new motherboard that will use an Arduino nano rather than a Teensy because MAAAAAN Arduino is a thousand times easier to make a midi controller with (plus they sell them for 8 bucks in my neighbourhood) heres a preview of what thatll look like... I'm definitely going to add a few things to this board though (I really need to add lights, an Arp and would like to add a delay effect using a cheapo pedal I put together this month) but this will involve adding some multiplexers to this board.... (thankfully I learned all about that last year) ....but you get the picture .....make tiny boards. attach them to one big board using ribbon cable then attach it to the axoloti and booyah. really fun synth time. the graphic design for the controlboard is going to be genuinely hilarious. I'll save that for when its done, but here's an early (boring) version I did a while back that I will not end up using......(I'm calling this synth SATAN-2...named in party by the juno-6 which this synth will end up being partially modelled after and also a reference to this new, lame, threat of nuclear war time this little guys was designed during) Ill update this in a couple months when its all done. The graphic design is going to be hilarious and will involve nukes. oh yeah! the keys are from an M-audio 49 key controller. Its the most basic controller I could find and cost about 70 bucks used. I think it was worth it but I'm convinced I could find the same components somewhere online for much cheaper...time will tell.

item.title: Retro lookin synth (work in progress)
item.dc:creator: @Androoclops
item.description:
@Androoclops wrote:

Simple usb midi controller. Just the guts of a m audio 49 key in there (I'll add the mod wheels this weekend I think). The simpler the keyboard the better - as for the pots, 16 connect to the axo directlyz the others and the switches go to an Arduino nano, then to the 5 pin midi input on the Axoloti. ....super fun project so far. Totally going to buy another 2 Axoloti's when I have some extra dough and gunna make something totally bananas

Read full topic

item.title: Retro lookin synth (work in progress)
item.dc:creator: @mongrol
item.description:
@mongrol wrote:

How are you handling the keyboard? Is it just midi or have you reverse engineered the matrix on it somehow?

Read full topic

item.title: Retro lookin synth (work in progress)
item.dc:creator: @axoman
item.description:
@axoman wrote:

That's handy then

Read full topic

item.title: Retro lookin synth (work in progress)
item.dc:creator: @Androoclops
item.description:
@Androoclops wrote:

Silkscreening was deifintely my first choice, I was exploring some other options and just the other day found out my sister and her husband both do silkscreening in their spare time....ill eventually learn how to do it myself but in the meantime im totally gunna get them to do it!

You're absolutely right about the wood choice - I used pine to learn with. I'm going to eventually switch over to some higher quality wood once I get all my switches and boards and whatnot in the same room together.

Read full topic

item.title: Retro lookin synth (work in progress)
item.dc:creator: @axoman
item.description:
@axoman wrote:

That looks very nice, Androoclops, and I like the name, but have you decided how you're going to get whatever graphic design you settle on, onto the aluminium panel?

The printable surface is nice and flat, so I suppose you could do some in-house silk-screening

Looks like you made a very fine job of folding the aluminium, but I'm surprised you chose pine for the wooden parts. Synths are generally a luxury item (especially custom-builds), so personally I would have chosen a hardwood rather than pine.

Read full topic

item.title: Retro lookin synth (work in progress)
item.dc:creator: @Androoclops
item.description:
@Androoclops wrote:

Here's where I'm at so far.

IMG_20180119_141728821.jpg3258x2443 1.66 MB

I started this project last year and have learned so many things along the way I have genuinely no idea where to start lol

You might think the inside of this is a huge mess and the connections to that many potentiometers ended up being noise as a result of - it was! - but I came up with a simple solution to fix all this that was actually super inexpensive. I designed a few little breakout boards in Eagle that hold the potentiometers in place (and this keeps them nicely spaced too)

IMG_20180119_143124512.jpg3258x2443 1.46 MB

IMG_20180119_143133342_BURST001.jpg3258x2443 1.44 MB

I use ribbon cable to connect these tiny little boards
IMG_20180119_143139457.jpg3258x2443 1.45 MB

To a motherboard!
IMG_20180119_143200491.jpg3258x2443 2.22 MB

This mother board was the first one one I came up with and I totally messed it up (it was one of the very first things I ever made in Eagle so meh) it had connections for the axoloti to connect to 16 pots directly, then the rest connected to a teensy....I really fucked up the design of it and it was a total loss - but i learned a lot during the process.

Heres what the interiors looks like right now. Its pretty tidy and has a lot of space for at least one Axoloti and a couple other boards to rest comfortably

IMG_20180119_142950772_BURST000_COVER_TOP.jpg3258x2443 1.93 MB

Now of course this wouldnt be a very interesting synth if it was nothing but potentiometers so I made a few different flavours of the small breakout boards that can be used for a number of different things (switches, leds, you name it!)

IMG_20180119_143358139.jpg3258x2443 2.54 MB

You'll notice that currently my synth is missing switches entirely - this is because I found some really nice looking switches that I like a lot more than the ones I designed these boards for so I'm waiting for my new boards for those switches to arrive. Also, making square holes in sheet metal is a huge pain in the ass so I've designed some little enclosure type things to hold my new square switches in circular holes.....also waiting for a new motherboard that will use an Arduino nano rather than a Teensy because MAAAAAN Arduino is a thousand times easier to make a midi controller with (plus they sell them for 8 bucks in my neighbourhood) heres a preview of what thatll look like...

mobo.png660x533 17.3 KB

I'm definitely going to add a few things to this board though (I really need to add lights, an Arp and would like to add a delay effect using a cheapo pedal I put together this month) but this will involve adding some multiplexers to this board.... (thankfully I learned all about that last year) ....but you get the picture .....make tiny boards. attach them to one big board using ribbon cable then attach it to the axoloti and booyah. really fun synth time.

the graphic design for the controlboard is going to be genuinely hilarious. I'll save that for when its done, but here's an early (boring) version I did a while back that I will not end up using......(I'm calling this synth SATAN-2...named in party by the juno-6 which this synth will end up being partially modelled after and also a reference to this new, lame, threat of nuclear war time this little guys was designed during)

SATAN-2-alt-hue_low_res.png1500x463 81.5 KB

Ill update this in a couple months when its all done. The graphic design is going to be hilarious and will involve nukes.

oh yeah! the keys are from an M-audio 49 key controller. Its the most basic controller I could find and cost about 70 bucks used. I think it was worth it but I'm convinced I could find the same components somewhere online for much cheaper...time will tell.
